intro: Salmea scandens var. genuina, commonly known as the climbing salmea, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is characterized by its trailing or climbing growth habit, with slender stems that can reach several meters in length. The plant produces small, delicate flowers that are typically pale pink to white in color, arranged in clusters along the stems. Its leaves are ovate to elliptical in shape, with a smooth or slightly hairy surface depending on the variety. Native to certain regions of South America, it thrives in warm, humid environments and is often found in disturbed or semi-shade habitats.
